HRMS (ESI) calcd for C24H33N4O13P2 [M – H]−, 647.1519; found, 647.1525.

    Trisodium Cytidin-5′-yl-[(1R,3R,4R)-3-benzyloxy-4-acetamido-1-cyclopentyl-phosphonatomethyl]-phosphate (5R)

    This compound was prepared in the same manner as described in the preparation of 5S. Quantities: 47d (210.7 mg, 0.16 mmol), Pd/C (421.4 mg, 10%), 1,4-cyclohexadiene (1.61 g, 1.9 mL, 19.08 mmol, 97%), EtOH (4.8 mL), and eluent (H2O → MeOH/H2O = 1:1), affording crude product 5R (51.8 mg, 50% yield). The diastereoisomers were further separated by preparative RP-HPLC, converted to the form of sodium salt by ion-exchange (IR 120 Na+), and lyophilized from water to give 5Rs and 5Rl as white powder. 5Rs: RP-HPLC, column B, 0–16 min linear gradient 8–9.5% CH3CN, 100 mM NH4HCO3 buffer (pH = 8.4), 15 mL/min flow; tR = 11.95 min; [α]D30 = +0.7 (c = 0.3, H2O). 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 7.96 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.41–7.35 (m, 5H), 6.09 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 5.93 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 4.61 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H), 4.55 (d, J = 11.4 Hz, 1H), 4.31 (t, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 4.28–4.17 (m, 5H), 4.10–4.07 (m, 1H), 3.91 (dt, J = 7.2, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 2.52–2.48 (m, 1H), 2.38 (dt, J = 12.6, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 2.12 (dt, J = 13.8, 9.6 Hz, 1H), 1.92 (s, 3H), 1.68–1.62 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, D2O) δ 174.0, 166.9, 158.3, 142.1, 138.2, 129.4, 129.2, 128.9, 97.1, 90.4, 85.3, 83.3 (d, J = 9.1 Hz), 76.4 (dd, J = 152.5, 15.1 Hz), 75.2, 72.1, 69.4, 64.8, 55.4, 37.6, 34.2 (d, J = 7.6 Hz), 33.8 (d, J = 4.5 Hz), 22.7. 31P NMR (162 MHz, D2O) δ 14.68, 0.56. HRMS (ESI) calcd for C24H33N4O13P2 [M – H]−, 647.1519; found, 647.1537. 5Rl: RP-HPLC, column B, 0–16 min linear gradient 8–9.5% CH3CN, 100 mM NH4HCO3 buffer (pH = 8.4), 15 mL/min flow; tR = 12.58 min; [α]D30 = −3.7 (c = 0.4, H2O). 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 7.98 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.41–7.34 (m, 5H), 6.09 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 5.90 (d, J = 3.0 Hz, 1H), 4.60 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H), 4.53 (d, J = 11.4 Hz, 1H), 4.32 (t, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 4.28–4.19 (m, 5H), 4.05 (dt, J = 9.6, 4.8 Hz, 1H), 3.91 (dt, J = 8.4, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 2.50 (brs, 1H), 2.27 (dt, J = 12.6, 6.0 Hz, 1H), 2.17 (dt, J = 13.8, 10.2 Hz, 1H), 1.89 (s, 3H), 1.68–1.62 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, D2O) δ 173.9, 166.9, 158.3, 142.0, 138.2, 129.3, 129.1, 128.9, 97.0, 90.3, 85.0, 83.0 (d, J = 9.1 Hz), 77.2 (d, J = 157.0 Hz), 75.2, 72.1, 69.2 (d, J = 7.6 Hz), 64.3, 55.3, 37.3, 35.0 (d, J = 9.1 Hz), 32.6 (d, J = 6.0 Hz), 22.6. 31P NMR (162 MHz, D2O) δ 14.95, 0.36. HRMS (ESI) calcd for C24H33N4O13P2 [M – H]−, 647.1519; found, 647.1525.

    Trisodium Cytidin-5′-yl-[(1R,3R,4S)-3-benzyloxy-4-acetamidomethyl-1-cyclopentyl-phosphonatomethyl]-phosphate (6)

    This compound was prepared in the same manner as described in the preparation of 5S. Quantities: 47e (68.4 mg, 0.051 mmol), Pd/C (136.8 mg, 10%), 1,4-cyclohexadiene (508.2 mg, 0.60 mL, 6.120 mmol, 97%), EtOH (2.2 mL), and eluent (H2O → MeOH/H2O = 1:1), affording crude product 6 (17.6 mg, 52% yield). The diastereoisomers were further separated by preparative RP-HPLC, converted to the form of sodium salt by ion-exchange (IR 120 Na+) and lyophilized from water to give 6s and 6l as white powder. 6s: RP-HPLC, column B, 0–16 min linear gradient 8–11.5% CH3CN, 100 mM NH4HCO3 buffer (pH = 8.4), 15 mL/min flow; tR = 12.65 min; [α]D30 = −3.6 (c = 0.2, H2O). 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 8.01 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.41–7.37 (m, 5H), 6.08 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 5.93 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 4.59 (d, J = 11.4 Hz, 1H), 4.46 (d, J = 11.4 Hz, 1H), 4.33 (t, J = 6.0 Hz,, 1H), 4.26–4.17 (m, 5H), 3.75 (dt, J = 8.4, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 3.20 (dd, J = 13.8, 7.2 Hz, 5H), 3.12 (dd, J = 13.8, 7.2 Hz, 1H), 2.47 (dt, J = 12.6, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 2.41 (brs, 1H), 2.18–2.12 (m, 1H), 1.99–1.93 (m, 1H), 1.92 (s, 3H), 1.64 (td, J = 11.4, 9.0 Hz, 1H), 1.54 (ddd, J = 12.6, 7.8, 4.8 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, D2O) δ 174.7, 166.9, 158.3, 142.2, 138.2, 129.4, 129.3, 128.9, 97.1, 90.5, 84.1, 83.4 (d, J = 9.1 Hz), 79.0 (d, J = 149.5 Hz), 75.3, 71.9, 69.2, 64.5 (d, J = 4.5 Hz), 43.6, 43.1, 38.4, 35.1 (d, J = 4.5 Hz), 31.5 (d, J = 7.6 Hz), 22.6. 31P NMR (162 MHz, D2O) δ 14.38, 0.70. HRMS (ESI) calcd for C25H35N4O13P2 [M – H]−, 661.1676; found, 661.1675. 6l: RP-HPLC, column B, 0–16 min linear gradient 8–11.5% CH3CN, 100 mM NH4HCO3 buffer (pH = 8.4), 15 mL/min flow; tR = 13.77 min; [α]D30 = −7.1 (c = 0.3, H2O). 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ 7.98 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.45–7.35 (m, 5H), 6.11 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 5.94 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 4.56 (d, J = 11.2 Hz, 1H), 4.45 (d, J = 11.2 Hz, 1H), 4.33 (t, J = 5.6 Hz, 1H), 4.30–4.22 (m, 5H), 3.76 (dt, J = 8.4, 6.4 Hz, 1H), 3.21 (dd, J = 13.2, 6.8 Hz, 1H), 3.10 (dd, J = 13.6, 6.8 Hz, 1H), 2.43 (brs, 1H), 2.32 (dt, J = 12.4, 6.4 Hz, 1H), 2.10–2.07 (m, 1H), 2.04–1.96 (m, 1H), 1.91 (s, 3H), 1.68–1.62 (m, 1H), 1.59–1.55 (m, 1H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, D2O) δ 174.6, 166.9, 158.3, 142.2, 138.3, 129.3, 129.1, 128.9, 97.1, 90.3, 83.8, 83.1 (d, J = 9.1 Hz), 78.1 (d, J = 154.0 Hz), 75.2, 72.0, 69.0, 64.0, 43.7, 43.2, 37.9, 36.5 (d, J = 7.6 Hz), 29.1, 22.6. 31P NMR (162 MHz, D2O) δ 14.36, 0.42. HRMS (ESI) calcd for C25H35N4O13P2 [M – H]−, 661.1676; found, 661.1702.

    Trisodium Cytidin-5′-yl-[phosphonato-1-((2S,3S)-2-benzyloxy-3-acetamido-methyl-cyclopentyl)]-phosphate (48)

    This compound was prepared in the same manner as described in the preparation of 5S. Quantities: 47f (16.1 mg, 0.012 mmol), Pd/C (16.1 mg, 10%), 1,4-cyclohexadiene (59.3 mg, 70 μL, 0.720 mmol, 97%), EtOH (0.5 mL), and eluent (H2O → MeOH/H2O = 1:1), affording crude product 48 (5.8 mg, 73% yield). The diastereoisomers were further separated by preparative RP-HPLC, converted to the form of sodium salt by ion-exchange (IR 120 Na+), and lyophilized from water to give 48s and 48l as white powder. 48s: RP-HPLC, column A, 6.0% CH3CN, 0.05 M TEAB (triethylammonium bicarbonate (pH 7.2–7.5)) buffer, 15 mL/min flow; tR = 6.13 min; [α]D30 = −22.2 (c = 0.9, H2O). 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 7.98 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H6′), 7.37–7.33 (m, 5H, Ar), 6.11 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H7′), 5.77 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H, H1′), 4.92 (d, J = 11.4 Hz, 1H, PhCH2), 4.54 (d, J = 11.4 Hz, 1H, PhCH2), 4.41 (dd, J = 7.2, 4.8 Hz, 1H, H3′), 4.34–4.28 (m, 2H, H5′α, H5′β), 4.12–4.10 (m, 1H, H4′), 3.91 (ddd, J = 9.6, 5.4, 4.2 Hz, 1H, H2), 3.50–3.49 (m, 1H, H2′), 3.28 (dd, J = 13.2, 5.4 Hz, 1H, H6α), 3.13 (dd, J = 13.8, 6.6 Hz, 1H, H6β), 2.43–2.33 (m, 2H, H3, H4α), 2.27 (td, J = 15.6, 9.0 Hz, 1H, H4β), 2.00–1.94 (m, 1H, H5α), 1.87 (s, 3H, CH3), 1.37–1.31 (m, 1H, H5β). 13C NMR (151 MHz, D2O) δ 174.7 (CH3CO), 164.7 (C8′), 155.2 (C9′), 142.8 (C6′), 138.9 (Ph), 129.2 (Ph), 129.1 (Ph), 128.8 (Ph), 96.4 (C7′), 90.7 (C1′), 86.0 (dd, J = 157.0, 7.6 Hz C1), 85.9 (dd, J = 6.0, 3.0 Hz C2), 82.7 (d, J = 6.0 Hz C4′), 75.1 (C2′), 74.0 (PhCH2), 68.2 (C3′), 64.2 (d, J = 6.0 Hz C5′), 43.1 (d, J = 9.1 Hz C3), 42.1 (C6), 32.2 (d, J = 6.0 Hz C4), 23.3 (d, J = 9.1 Hz C5), 22.6 (CH3). 31P NMR (162 MHz, D2O) δ 17.21, −2.48. HRMS (ESI) calcd for C24H33N4O13P2 [M – H]−, 647.1519; found, 647.1522. 48l: RP-HPLC, column A, 6.0% CH3CN, 0.05 M TEAB (triethylammonium bicarbonate (pH 7.2–7.5)) buffer, 15 mL/min flow; tR = 10.55 min; [α]D30 = −11.5 (c = 0.5, H2O). 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 7.94 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H6′), 7.44–7.35 (m, 5H, Ar), 6.02 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H7′), 5.92 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H, H1′), 4.99 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H, PhCH2), 4.61 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H, PhCH2), 4.35 (t, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H, H3′), 4.31–4.29 (m, 1H, H5′α), 4.26 (t, J = 4.2 Hz, 1H, H2′), 4.24–4.19 (m, 3H, H4′, H2, H5′β), 3.16 (dd, J = 13.8, 6.0 Hz, 1H, H6α), 3.08 (dd, J = 13.8, 7.2 Hz, 1H, H6β), 2.44–2.34 (m, 2H, H4α, H4β), 2.33–2.28 (m, 1H, H3),1.84 (s, 3H, CH3), 1.83–1.77 (m, 1H, H5α), 1.55–1.48 (m, 1H, H5β). 13C NMR (151 MHz, D2O) δ 174.6 (CH3CO), 166.8 (C8′), 158.3 (C9′), 142.1 (C6′), 139.0 (Ph), 129.6 (Ph), 129.2 (Ph), 128.8 (Ph), 97.2 (C7′), 90.4 (C2), 90.4 (d, J = 160.1, 9.1 Hz C1), 90.2 (C1′), 83.1 (d, J = 9.1 Hz C4′), 75.0 (C2′), 73.9 (PhCH2), 69.4 (C3′), 64.5 (d, J = 6.0 Hz C5′), 42.7 (C3), 42.4 (C6), 32.0 (C4), 24.6 (d, J = 6.0 Hz C5), 22.5 (CH3). 31P NMR (162 MHz, D2O) δ 15.60 (d, J = 25.9 Hz), −3.45 (d, J = 25.9 Hz). HRMS (ESI) calcd for C24H33N4O13P2 [M – H]−, 647.1519; found, 647.1511.

    Trisodium Cytidin-5′-yl-[(3-phenoxy)phenylphosphonatomethyl]-phosphate (49)

    This compound was prepared in the same manner as described in the preparation of 2. Quantities: 47g (61.2 mg, 0.05 mmol), Pd/C (61.2 mg, 10%), 1,4-cyclohexadiene (485.3 mg, 573 μL, 5.88 mmol, 97%), DMF (1.0 mL), and eluent (H2O → MeOH/H2O = 1:1), affording crude product 49 (17.0 mg, 60% yield). The diastereoisomers were further separated by preparative RP-HPLC, converted to the form of sodium salt by ion-exchange (IR 120 Na+), and lyophilized from water to give 49s and 49l as white powder. 49s: RP-HPLC, column B, λ = 260 nm, 0–12 min linear gradient 4–8% CH3CN, 100 mM NH4HCO3 buffer (pH = 8.4), 15 mL/min flow; tR = 10.10 min. 49l: RP-HPLC, column B, λ = 260 nm, 0–12 min linear gradient 4–8% CH3CN, 100 mM NH4HCO3 buffer (pH = 8.4), 15 mL/min flow; tR = 10.80 min. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ = 7.66 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.34–7.29 (m, 3H), 7.26 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.15 (brs, 1H), 7.11 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 6.98–6.96 (m, 2H), 6.84–6.82 (m, 1H), 6.03 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 5.80 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 5.02 (dd, J = 13.2, 10.4 Hz, 1H), 3.97–3.95 (m, 2H), 3.90–3.86 (m, 2H), 3.70 ppm (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H). The spectroscopic data coincide with the previous report.(36)

    RP-HPLC Based Sialyltransferase Assay

    The assay was performed according to the UV/RP-HPLC method developed by Schmidt group.(30) For details of the procedures, see Supporting Information.

    This article references 82 other publications.

    1. 1
      Angata, T.; Varki, A. Chemical diversity in the sialic acids and related alpha-keto acids: an evolutionary perspective Chem. Rev. 2002, 102, 439– 469 DOI: 10.1021/cr000407m
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Chemical Diversity in the Sialic Acids and Related α-Keto Acids: An Evolutionary Perspective
      Angata, Takashi; Varki, Ajit
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, D. C.) (2002), 102 (2), 439-469CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review with refs. on the evolutionary perspective, occurrence, biosynthesis, and structural diversity of sialic acids in bacteria and natural proteins.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XhtFansg%253D%253D&md5=6668c144c9fa363819c4054260265d77
    2. 2
      Varki, A. Glycan-based interactions involving vertebrate sialic-acid-recognizing proteins Nature 2007, 446, 1023– 1029 DOI: 10.1038/nature05816
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Glycan-based interactions involving vertebrate sialic-acid-recognizing proteins
      Varki, Ajit
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2007), 446 (7139), 1023-1029CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. All cells in nature are covered by a dense and complex array of carbohydrates. Given their prominence on cell surfaces, it is not surprising that these glycans mediate and/or modulate many cellular interactions. Proteins that bind sialic acid, a sugar that is found on the surface of the cell and on secreted proteins in vertebrates, are involved in a broad range of biol. processes, including intercellular adhesion, signaling and microbial attachment. Studying the roles of such proteins in vertebrates has improved our understanding of normal physiol., disease and human evolution.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXksFersr8%253D&md5=1695b2dc782f39d76ea0039a118ffaa2
    3. 3
      Severi, E.; Hood, D. W.; Thomas, G. H. Sialic acid utilization by bacterial pathogens Microbiology 2007, 153, 2817– 2822 DOI: 10.1099/mic.0.2007/009480-0
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Sialic acid utilization by bacterial pathogens
      Severi, Emmanuele; Hood, Derek W.; Thomas, Gavin H.
      Microbiology (Reading, United Kingdom) (2007), 153 (9), 2817-2822CODEN: MROBEO; ISSN:1350-0872. (Society for General Microbiology)
      A review. Sialic acid occupies the terminal position within glycan mols. on the surfaces of many vertebrate cells, where it functions in diverse cellular processes such as intercellular adhesion and cell signaling. Pathogenic bacteria have evolved to use this mol. beneficially in at least two different ways: they can coat themselves in sialic acid, providing resistance to components of the host's innate immune response, or they can use it as a nutrient. Sialic acid itself is either synthesized de novo by these bacteria or scavenged directly from the host. In this mini-review the authors will summarize recent findings relating to sialic acid transport, modification of sialic acid by O-acetylation, and the mechanisms of sialic acid-mediated complement resistance.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtFKrt7bL&md5=dc48dc4750e7b5eb1a405da6ccf288e1
    4. 4
      Varki, N. M.; Varki, A. Diversity in cell surface sialic acid presentations: implications for biology and disease Lab. Invest. 2007, 87, 851– 857 DOI: 10.1038/labinvest.3700656
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Diversity in cell surface sialic acid presentations: implications for biology and disease
      Varki, Nissi M.; Varki, Ajit
      Laboratory Investigation (2007), 87 (9), 851-857CODEN: LAINAW; ISSN:0023-6837. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Sialic acids (Sias) are typically found as terminal monosaccharides attached to cell surface glycoconjugates. They play many important roles in many physiol. and pathol. processes, including microbe binding that leads to infections, regulation of the immune response, the progression and spread of human malignancies and in certain aspects of human evolution. This review will provide some examples of these diverse roles of Sias and briefly address immunohistochem. approaches to their detection.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXptFensbg%253D&md5=a36aef1b2b057aec45c6cbe61f35024e
    5. 5
      Harduin-Lepers, A.; Krzewinski-Recchi, M. A.; Colomb, F.; Foulquier, F.; Groux-Degroote, S.; Delannoy, P. Sialyltransferases functions in cancers Front. Biosci., Elite Ed. 2012, 4, 499– 515 DOI: 10.2741/E396
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Sialytransferases functions in cancers
      Harduin-Lepers, Anne; Krzewinski-Recchi, Marie-Ange; Colomb, Florent; Foulquier, Francois; Groux-Degroote, Sophie; Delannoy, Philippe
      Frontiers in Bioscience, Elite Edition (2012), E4 (1), 499-515CODEN: FBEEAS; ISSN:1945-0508. (Frontiers in Bioscience)
      A review. Abnormally elevated levels of sialylated tumor assocd. carbohydrate antigens are frequently described at the surface of cancer cells and/or secreted in biol. fluids. It is now well established that this over-expression may result from deregulation in sialyltransferases enzymic activity involved in their biosynthesis, but the precise mol. mechanisms remain unknown. Twenty different human sialyltransferases preside to the sialylation of glycoconjugates, either glycolipids or glycoproteins. This review summarizes the current knowledge on human sialyltransferases implicated in the altered expression of sialylated tumor assocd. antigens, the mol. basis of their regulated expression in cancer cells and the various tools developed by researchers and clinicians for their study in pathol. samples.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XjsVyksbo%253D&md5=e9703de741412e4de32dacfea2753062
    6. 6
      Dall Olio, F.; Malagolini, N.; di Stefano, G.; Minni, F.; Marrano, D.; Serafini-Cessi, F. Increased CMP-NeuAc:Gal beta 1,4GlcNAc-R alpha 2,6 sialyltransferase activity in human colorectal cancer tissues Int. J. Cancer 1989, 44, 434– 439 DOI: 10.1002/ijc.2910440309
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Increased CMP-NeuAc:Gal beta 1,4GlcNAc-R alpha 2,6 sialyltransferase activity in human colorectal cancer tissues
      Dall'Olio F; Malagolini N; di Stefano G; Minni F; Marrano D; Serafini-Cessi F
      International journal of cancer (1989), 44 (3), 434-9 ISSN:0020-7136.
      The sialyltransferase activities of 10 human colorectal specimens were compared with those of the corresponding adjacent normal mucosa. Using asialofetuin as an acceptor we found, in tumor tissues of 9 out of 10 patients, an increased sialyltransferase activity towards the N-linked chains as determined upon peptide-N4-(N-acetyl-beta-glucosaminyl)asparagine amidase (PNGase) treatment. On the contrary, the activity towards the O-linked chains was not significantly changed. When the specificity of the sialyltransferase acting on N-linked chains was investigated by using N-acetyl-lactosamine (Gal beta 1,4GlcNAc) as an acceptor, we found that the alpha 2,6 sialyltransferase activity expressed by both normal and tumor colorectal tissues was far higher than the alpha 2,3-activity and that alpha 2,6 was the only sialyltransferase activity increased in tumor tissues. Kinetic analysis revealed that normal and tumor alpha 2,6 sialyltransferases have the same apparent Km for the acceptor substrate (469 and 465 microns), but normal enzyme has a higher Km for CMP-NeuAc (303 microns) than the tumor enzyme (50 microns). The higher affinity of tumor enzyme for the nucleotide-sugar might partially explain its increased activity in tumor tissues. In addition, tumor tissues contain a lower amount of sialic acid despite the increase in alpha 2,6 sialyltransferase activity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaL1MznvFCnsg%253D%253D&md5=77de5127f71abb44960ecd1f02e015fd
    7. 7
      Yamamoto, H.; Saito, T.; Kaneko, Y.; Kersey, D.; Yong, V. W.; Bremer, E. G.; Mkrdichian, E.; Cerullo, L.; Leestma, J.; Moskal, J. R. alpha2,3-sialyltransferase mRNA and alpha2,3-linked glycoprotein sialylation are increased in malignant gliomas Brain Res. 1997, 755, 175– 179 DOI: 10.1016/S0006-8993(97)00241-2
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      α2,3-Sialyltransferase mRNA and α2,3-linked glycoprotein sialylation are increased in malignant gliomas
      Yamamoto, Hirotaka; Saito, Tasuku; Kaneko, Yoichi; Kersey, Donna; Yong, Voon Wee; Bremer, Eric G.; Mkrdichian, Edward; Cerullo, Leonard; Leestma, Jan; Moskal, Joseph R.
      Brain Research (1997), 755 (1), 175-179CODEN: BRREAP; ISSN:0006-8993. (Elsevier)
      CMP-NeuAc:Galβ1,3(4)GlcNAc α2,3-sialyltransferase (α2,3-ST) mRNA was expressed in human glioma specimens, human fetal astrocytes, and a panel of brain tumor cell lines. Maackia amurensis agglutinin staining revealed the presence of α2,3-linked sialic acids on glioma cell surfaces and extracellular matrixes whereas normal human adult astrocytes were neg. Increased expression of α2,3-linked glycoprotein sialylation may play a role in glial tumorigenesis.

    9. 9
      Wang, P. H.; Li, Y. F.; Juang, C. M.; Lee, Y. R.; Chao, H. T.; Tsai, Y. C.; Yuan, C. C. Altered mRNA expression of sialyltransferase in squamous cell carcinomas of the cervix Gynecol. Oncol. 2001, 83, 121– 127 DOI: 10.1006/gyno.2001.6358

      9
      Altered mRNA expression of sialyltransferase in squamous cell carcinomas of the cervix
      Wang, Peng-Hui; Li, Ywan Feng; Juang, Chi-Mou; Lee, Yan-Ru; Chao, Hsiang-Tai; Tsai, Ying-Chieh; Yuan, Chiou-Chung
      Gynecologic Oncology (2001), 83 (1), 121-127CODEN: GYNOA3; ISSN:0090-8258. (Academic Press)
      Increased sialylation has been reported in various kinds of cancers, but to date, sialylation of cervical carcinoma has never been evaluated. This study of the changes in mRNA (mRNA) expression of the four sialyltransferases (ST3Gal I, ST3Gal III, ST3Gal IV, and ST6Gal I) in a normal cervix and that with FIGO stage IB1 squamous cell carcinoma was undertaken to assess the extent of sialylation assocd. with establishment of the carcinoma. Alterations in ST mRNA expression in FIGO IB1 cervical cancer (n = 30) and normal cervixes (n = 30) were examd. by semiquant. reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).Results. ST6Gal I expression was enhanced in squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix (P = 0.026, Mann-Whitney U test), but mRNA expression from the other three STs (ST3Gal I, ST3Gal III, and ST3Gal IV) was significantly down-expressed in squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix compared to the normal cervix (P = 0.003, P < 0.001, and P = 0.001, resp.). High ST6Gal I expression was assocd. with more invasive properties of cervical cancer, such as deep stromal invasion, lymph or vascular space involvement, and poor differentiation (P = 0.010, P < 0.001, P < 0.001, resp.). A combination of enhanced ST6Gal I mRNA expression and decreased mRNA expression from ST3Gal I, ST3Gal III, and ST3Gal IV might be important in cervical cancer. Future studies will investigate whether RT-PCR detection of the expression of these enzymes can be helpful for prognostic purposes. (c) 2001 Academic Press.

      Wang, X.; Zhang, L.-H.; Ye, X.-S. Recent development in the design of sialyltransferase inhibitors Med. Res. Rev. 2003, 23, 32– 47 DOI: 10.1002/med.10030

      13
      Recent development in the design of sialyltransferase inhibitors
      Wang, Xiaofang; Zhang, Li-He; Ye, Xin-Shan
      Medicinal Research Reviews (2003), 23 (1), 32-47CODEN: MRREDD; ISSN:0198-6325. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      A review. Sialylation at the non-reducing end of glycoconjugates is an important biol. process in cellular recognitions, tumor metastases, and immune responses, which are mediated by a family of enzymes known as sialytransferases. Inhibition of sialytransferases may prove useful in elucidating the biol. functions of sialylation and may have therapeutic applications. This review summarizes the recent development in this field with particular focus on the strategies used for the design of carbohydrate mimetics and the structure-activity relationships of substrate-based sialytransferase inhibitors.

      15
      Sialyltransferase inhibitors
      Jung, Karl-Heinz; Schwoerer, Ralf; Schmidt, Richard R.
      Trends in Glycoscience and Glycotechnology (2003), 15 (85), 275-289CODEN: TGGLEE; ISSN:0915-7352. (FCCA)
      A review. Sialylation of glycoproteins and glycolipids plays an important role in many cell surface processes; of special interest in this context are changes in tissue involved in diseases and esp. changes during infections. Therefore, inhibitors of sialyltransferases regulating sialylation might be of medicinal interest, esp. in the therapy of virus and cancer diseases. The present paper reviews the development of sialyltransferase inhibitors; thus acceptor analogs, donor analogs, transition-state analogs, and bisubstrate analogs were designed based on sialic acid derivs. as well as on structural mimetics. This way, very potent sialyltransferase inhibitors with inhibition consts. in the low nanomolar range have been recently found.

      21
      Sialyltransferase inhibitors: consideration of molecular shape and charge/hydrophobic interactions
      Kumar, Rishi; Nasi, Ravindranath; Bhasin, Milan; Huan Khieu, Nam; Hsieh, Margaret; Gilbert, Michel; Jarrell, Harold; Zou, Wei; Jennings, Harold J.
      Carbohydrate Research (2013), 378 (), 45-55CODEN: CRBRAT; ISSN:0008-6215. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      In order to evaluate the importance of mol. shape of inhibitor mols. and the charge/H-bond and hydrophobic interactions, we synthesized three types of mols. and tested them against a sialyltransferase. The first type of compds. were designed as substrate mimics in which the phosphate in CMP-Neu5NAc was replaced by a non-hydrolysable, uncharged 1,2,3-triazole moiety. The second type of compd. contained a 2-deoxy-2,3-dehydro-acetylneuraminic moiety which was linked to cytidine through its carboxylic acid and amide linkers. In the third type of compd. the sialyl phosphate was substituted by an aryl sulfonamide which was then linked to cytidine. Inhibition study of these cytidine conjugates against Campylobacter jejuni sialyltransferase Cst 06 showed that the first type of mols. are competitive inhibitors, whereas the other two could only inhibit the enzyme non-competitively. The results indicate that although the binding specificity may be guided by mol. shape and H-bond interaction, the charge and hydrophobic interactions contributed most to the binding affinity.

      28
      Systematic Syntheses and Inhibitory Activities of Bisubstrate-Type Inhibitors of Sialyltransferases
      Hinou, Hiroshi; Sun, Xue-Long; Ito, Yukishige
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2003), 68 (14), 5602-5613CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      Bisubstrate-type sialyltransferase inhibitors, having CMP-NeuAc and N-acetyllactosamine (or lactose) moieties connected by an alkanedithiol linker, were synthesized systematically. A uniform synthetic strategy was adopted that consists of consecutive couplings of three components (N-acetyllactosamine or lactose, sialic acid, and CMP), followed by oxidn. Due to the sensitivity of the compds. under alk. conditions, final deprotection required careful monitoring by 1H NMR. The inhibitory activities toward ST6N and ST3N indicated that both the structure of the acceptor moiety and the distance between donor and acceptor moieties were important.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29
      Synthesis of Bisubstrate and Donor Analogues of Sialyltransferase and Their Inhibitory Activities
      Izumi, Masayuki; Wada, Katsuhiro; Yuasa, Hideya; Hashimoto, Hironobu
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2005), 70 (22), 8817-8824CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      Sialyltransferases (STs) are involved in the biosynthesis of glycoconjugates with important biol. activities. Most STs utilize cytidine-5'-monophospho-N-acetylneuraminic acid (CMP-Neu5Ac) as a common donor substrate. A bisubstrate analog contg. the donor substrate (CMP-Neu5Ac mimic) and the acceptor substrate (galactose) was synthesized. Four donor analogs having the partial structure of the bisubstrate analog were also synthesized to support study of the structure-activity relationship. Each analog contains an ethylene group in place of the exocyclic anomeric oxygen of CMP-Neu5Ac. The bisubstrate analog exhibited only weak inhibitory activity to rat recombinant α-2,3- and α-2,6-ST (IC50 = 1.3, 2.4 mM). Conversion of the C-1 carboxylate of the Neu5Ac moiety to carboxyamide, hydroxymethyl, or methylene phosphate each resulted in a redn. in inhibitory activity. Among the synthesized analogs, cytidin-5'-yl sialylethylphosphonate (4) was the most potent inhibitor against rat recombinant α-2,3- and α-2,6-ST (IC50 = 0.047, 0.34 mM).
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Schaub, C.; Müller, B.; Schmidt, R. R. New sialyltransferase inhibitors based on CMP-quinic acid: development of a new sialyltransferase assay Glycoconjugate J. 1998, 15, 345– 354 DOI: 10.1023/A:1006917717161

      30
      New sialyltransferase inhibitors based on CMP-quinic acid: development of a new sialyltransferase assay
      Schaub, Christoph; Muller, Bernd; Schmidt, Richard R.
      Glycoconjugate Journal (1998), 15 (4), 345-354CODEN: GLJOEW; ISSN:0282-0080. (Chapman & Hall)
      Quinic acid was transformed into phosphitamides which could be readily linked to a 5'-O-unprotected cytidine deriv.; ensuing oxidn. of the obtained phosphite triesters with tert-Bu hydroperoxide furnished the corresponding phosphate triesters. Hydrogenolytic debenzylation of the phosphate moiety, base catalyzed removal of acetyl protective groups, and basic hydrolysis of the Me ester of the quinic acid moiety furnished CMP-Neu5Ac analogs I [R = OH, R1 = H; R = H, R1 = NH= NH2, NHAc]. In order to measure their inhibition of sialyltransferases, a nonradioactive sialyltransferase assay [employed for a(2-6)-sialyltransferase from rat liver (EC 2.4.99.1)] based on reversed-phase HPLC sepn. of UV-labeled acceptor (p-nitrophenyl glycoside of N-acetyllactosamine) from the UV-labeled product (p-nitrophenyl glycoside of sialyl a(2-6')-N-acetyllactosamine) and p-nitrophenylalanine as internal std. was developed. The assay reproduced the reported KM values for CMP-Neu5Ac and N-acetyllactosamine and the K1 values for CDP. I [R = OH, R1 = H; R = H, R1 = NHAc] turned out to be potent sialyltransferase inhibitors.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Amann, F.; Schaub, C.; Müller, B.; Schmidt, R. R. New potent sialyltransferase inhibitors—synthesis of donor and of transition-state analogues of sialyl donor CMP-Neu5Ac Chem. - Eur. J. 1998, 4, 1106– 1115 DOI: 10.1002/(SICI)1521-3765(19980615)4:6<1106::AID-CHEM1106>3.0.CO;2-7
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31
      New potent sialyltransferase inhibitors - synthesis of donor and of transition-state analogs of sialyl donor CMP-Neu5Ac
      Amann, Franz; Schaub, Christoph; Muller, Bernd; Schmidt, Richard R.
      Chemistry--A European Journal (1998), 4 (6), 1106-1115CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      Enzymic sialyl transfer with CMP-Neu5Ac as donor can be inhibited by CDP. Therefore sialyl nucleotide phosphonates were synthesized as substrate analogs. With α(2-6)-sialyltransferase from rat liver (EC.2.4.99.1) only moderate inhibition was found for these compds. In order to obtain transition-state analogs of CMP-Neu5Ac different linkages between 2,3-dehydro-N-acetylneuraminol and CMP were generated. Compd. I exhibited excellent α(2-6)-sialyltransferase inhibition in the nanomolar range (Ki = 350 nM), resulting in a 130-fold higher affinity for the enzyme than CMP-Neu5Ac (KM = 46 μM).

      35
      Efficient sialyltransferase inhibitors based on glycosides of N-acetylglucosamine
      Schworer Ralf; Schmidt Richard R
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (8), 1632-7 ISSN:0002-7863.
      D-Glucosamine was transformed into phenyl and 2-benzoyloxyethyl N-acetylglucosamine beta-glycosides 6a and 6b, respectively. Transformation of 6a,b into 6-O-unprotected N-acetylglucosamine derivatives 9a,b permitted the generation of an aldehyde group in the 6-position. Treatment of these intermediates with base afforded unsaturated aldehyde derivatives 10a,b, which are structural mimics of 2,3-dehydroneuraminic acid. H-Phosphonate addition to the aldehyde group and attachment of the cytidine monophosphate residue to the generated hydroxy group gave fully protected transition state analogues of cytidine monophosphate-N-acetylneuraminic acid 14a,b. Liberation of the unprotected compounds 1ah,l and 1bh,l led to excellent inhibitors of alpha(2-6)-sialyltransferase from rat liver. Variation of the protective group cleavage procedure for 14a,b led to formal loss of phosphate, thus resulting in diene derivatives (E)-/(Z)-2a,b, which also exhibited inhibitory properties.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD387ltlWnsQ%253D%253D&md5=9618a971de63256a565c91e0b1a11bb5
    36. 36
      Skropeta, D.; Schwörer, R.; Haag, T.; Schmidt, R. R. Asymmetric synthesis and affinity of potent sialyltransferase inhibitors based on transition-state analogues Glycoconjugate J. 2004, 21, 205– 219 DOI: 10.1023/B:GLYC.0000045093.96413.62
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      36
      Asymmetric synthesis and affinity of potent sialyltransferase inhibitors based on transition-state analogs
      Skropeta, Danielle; Schwoerer, Ralf; Haag, Tobias; Schmidt, Richard R.
      Glycoconjugate Journal (2004), 21 (5), 205-219CODEN: GLJOEW; ISSN:0282-0080. (Kluwer Academic Publishers)
      Inhibitors that are structurally related to the transition-state model of the proposed SN1-type mechanism of sialyl transfer, exhibit particularly high binding affinities to α(2-6)sialyltransferases. Furthermore, replacing the neuraminyl residue with a simple aryl or heteroaryl ring and substituting the carboxylate group for a phosphonate moiety, improves both binding affinity and synthetic accessibility. Reported was the synthesis and inhibition of a wide range of novel, potent transition-state analog based α(2-6)sialyltransferase inhibitors comprising a planar anomeric carbon, an increased distance between the anomeric carbon and the CMP leaving group, and at least two neg. charges. Also presented was a short, efficient asym. synthesis of the most promising benzyl inhibitors, providing rapid access to large quantities of highly potent, stereochem.-pure (>96% de) inhibitors for further biol. investigation (e.g. the trisodium salt of (R)-I, Ki = 70 nM).
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Molecular architecture and biological reactions
      Pauling, Linus
      Chemical & Engineering News (1946), 24 (), 1375-7CODEN: CENEAR; ISSN:0009-2347.
      Answers to many basic problems of biology, such as nature of growth, mechanism of duplication of viruses and genes, action of enzymes, mechanism of physiol. activity of drugs, hormones and vitamins, and structure and action of nerve and brain tissue, may lie in knowledge of mol. structure and intermol. reactions gained by further probing into the dimensional range of approx. 10-100 A. The importance of shape as exemplified in the concept of complementariness of surface structures of antigen and antibody and other forms of biol. specificity is discussed.

      Heasley, B. Recent developments in the stereocontrolled synthesis of highly substituted cyclopentane core structures: from drug discovery research to natural product synthesis Curr. Org. Chem. 2014, 18, 641– 686 DOI: 10.2174/13852728113176660150
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      45
      Recent Developments in the Stereocontrolled Synthesis of Highly Substituted Cyclopentane Core Structures: From Drug Discovery Research to Natural Product Synthesis
      Heasley, Brian
      Current Organic Chemistry (2014), 18 (6), 641-686CODEN: CORCFE; ISSN:1385-2728. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. The cyclopentane motif has been utilized as an effective core scaffold for several highly successful medicinal chem. programs and, thus, has provided an under appreciated yet significant value for biomedical research. Moreover, the modern synthetic methods highlighted in this work offer a wealth of attractive and accessible technologies for the stereocontrolled construction of exceedingly complex cyclopentanoid chemotypes of natural and unnatural origin. It is contended that the cyclopentane framework should be regarded as a privileged scaffold for drug discovery research and that expanded screening campaigns of novel cyclopentane-based small mol. libraries for therapeutically relevant biol. properties will have a favorable impact on the development of the active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) of tomorrow.

      Shetty, A. K.; Peek, L. A. Peramivir for the treatment of influenza Expert Rev. Anti-Infect. Ther. 2012, 10, 123– 143 DOI: 10.1586/eri.11.174
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      48
      Peramivir for the treatment of influenza
      Shetty, Avinash K.; Peek, Leigh A.
      Expert Review of Anti-Infective Therapy (2012), 10 (2), 123-143CODEN: ERATCK; ISSN:1478-7210. (Expert Reviews Ltd.)
      A review. Peramivir (BioCryst Pharmaceuticals) is a novel investigational i.v. neuraminidase inhibitor that exhibits potent antiviral activity against influenza A and B viruses. Peramivir is created by a structure-based drug design and consists of a cyclopentane backbone with a pos. charged guanidinyl group and lipophilic side chains. Peramivir was made available in the USA through the Emergency Investigational New Drug regulations and under an Emergency Use Authorization for hospitalized patients with known or suspected influenza during the 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic. In trials involving ambulatory adult subjects, i.v. peramivir is safe and has a pharmacokinetic profile that supports once-daily dosing. The drug is licensed in Japan and South Korea and is currently undergoing Phase III trials in the USA. Viral resistance mechanisms to peramivir have not been fully delineated and ongoing surveillance is important. Given the serious health threat of influenza at all ages and limitations in vaccine delivery, peramivir is a promising addn. to the currently limited treatment options for the treatment of severe influenza infection.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XisVKhur8%253D&md5=0d07fd0d34d1249ec1a84c16f235b6fe

      55
      Reaction of methyl-4-methylene-2,3-O-isopropylidene-β-D-ribofuranoside with N-bromosuccinimide in aqueous tetrahydrofuran
      Ivanova, N. A.; Valiullina, Z. R.; Shitikova, O. V.; Miftakhov, M. S.
      Russian Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 43 (5), 742-746CODEN: RJOCEQ; ISSN:1070-4280. (Pleiades Publishing, Ltd.)
      Methyl-4-methylene-2,3-O-isopropylidene-β-D-ribofuranoside prepd. from D-ribose reacted in a system NBS-THF-H2O to give a mixt. of stereoisomeric products of regioselective bromohydroxylation of a double bond. The reaction involved a hydrolysis of the glycoside bond, but the acetonide protective group was retained. The mechanism of the selective hydrolysis originating from the ring-chain tautomerism of bromohydrins obtained was proved by the 1H NMR spectra of the steroisomeric methyl-5-deoxy-5-bromo-4-hydroxy-2,3-O-isopropylidene-β-D-ribofuranosides. By crotonic cyclization of the formed masked 1,4-dicarbonyl compds. at heating in benzene in the presence of neutral Al2O3 a new chiral cyclopentenone block, 2-bromo-4,5-isopropylideneoxycyclopent-2-en-1-one, was obtained in a low yield.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      57
      Catalytic Epoxidation of Alkenes with Oxone
      Denmark, Scott E.; Forbes, David C.; Hays, David S.; DePue, Jeffrey S.; Wilde, Richard G.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1995), 60 (5), 1391-407CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      A practical, general and efficient protocol for the catalytic epoxidn. of alkenes has been developed. The in situ generation of reactive dioxiranes capable of epoxidizing a variety of alkenes under biphasic conditions has been accomplished using phase transfer catalysts bearing a carbonyl group. Optimal epoxidn. conditions employ 10 mol% of 1-dodecyl-1-methyl-4-oxopiperidinium triflate in a CH2Cl2/pH 7.5-8.0 biphase using potassium monoperoxosulfate (Oxone) as the oxidant. Optimization of the conditions identified (1) slow addn. rate, (2) pH 7.5-8.0, (3) N-dodecyl chain, and (4) the triflate salt as key exptl. and structural variables. A selection of nine olefins was successfully oxidized to the corresponding epoxides in 83-96% yield.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      58
      Mixed solvents containing methanol as useful reaction media for unique chemoselective reductions within lithium borohydride
      Soai, Kenso; Ookawa, Atsuhiro
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1986), 51 (21), 4000-5CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
      The reducing ability of LiBH4 is greatly enhanced in mixed solvents contg. methanol. Esters, lactones, and epoxides are reduced chemoselectively more rapidly with LiBH4-MeOH (1 equiv. added at the beginning)-ether than with LiBH4-ether in the presence of other reducible groups such as carboxylic acid, chloride, nitro, and carbamoyl. Nitro, nitrile, and carboxyl, and primary and tertiary amide groups are reduced with LiBH4-MeOH (4 equiv. dropwise addn.)-diglyme(or THF). However, secondary amides derived from aliph. amines and metal carboxylate are not reduced. Thus, unique chemoselective redns. of primary amide in the presence of secondary amide or metal carboxylate are achieved.

      61
      A convenient and highly chemoselective method for the reductive acetylation of azides
      Rosen, Terry; Lico, Isabella M.; Chu, Daniel T. W.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1988), 53 (7), 1580-2CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
      Azides, e.g. I, react with AcSH to afford the corresponding acetamides, e.g. II, in good yield. The reaction is highly chemoselective. The transformation occurs under extremely mild conditions and has been accomplished in the presence of a wide variety of functional groups including tert-butoxycarbonyl and benzyl protecting groups, olefins, carboxylic esters and a methanesulfonate ester. This rapid reductive acetylation allows the introduction of a protected amino group into a mol. possessing functionality otherwise incompatible with the free amine.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXhsFShs7w%253D&md5=792396a9bdf31763f2cbced44e6ace61
    62. 62
      Kolakowski, R. V.; Shangguan, N.; Sauers, R. R.; Williams, L. J. Mechanism of thio acid/azide amidation J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 5695– 5702 DOI: 10.1021/ja057533y
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      62
      Mechanism of Thio Acid/Azide Amidation
      Kolakowski, Robert V.; Shangguan, Ning; Sauers, Ronald R.; Williams, Lawrence J.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (17), 5695-5702CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A combined exptl. and computational mechanistic study of amide formation from thio acids and azides is described. The data support two distinct mechanistic pathways dependent on the electronic character of the azide component. Relatively electron-rich azides undergo bimol. coupling with thiocarboxylates via an anion-accelerated [3+2] cycloaddn. to give a thiatriazoline. Highly electron-poor azides couple via bimol. union of the terminal nitrogen of the azide with sulfur of the thiocarboxylate to give a linear adduct. Cyclization of this intermediate gives a thiatriazoline. Decompn. to amide is found to proceed via retro-[3+2] cycloaddn. of the neutral thiatriazoline intermediates. Computational anal. (DFT, 6-31+G(d)) identified pathways by which both classes of azide undergo [3+2] cycloaddn. with thio acid to give thiatriazoline intermediates, although these paths are higher in energy than the thiocarboxylate amidations. These studies also establish that the reaction profile of electron-poor azides is attributable to a prior capture mechanism followed by intramol. acylation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xjt1yitbo%253D&md5=2b944c5e33ac52fb528626432d84aaf6

      A New DNA Building Block, 4'-Selenothymidine: Synthesis and Modification to 4'-Seleno-AZT as a Potential Anti-HIV Agent
      Alexander, Varughese; Choi, Won Jun; Chun, Jeongha; Kim, Hea Ok; Jeon, Ji Hye; Tosh, Dilip K.; Lee, Hyuk Woo; Chandra, Girish; Choi, Jungwon; Jeong, Lak Shin
      Organic Letters (2010), 12 (10), 2242-2245CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
      The first synthesis of 4'-selenothymidine, a novel DNA building block, and 4'-seleno-AZT was accomplished from 2-deoxy-D-ribose via stereoselective formation of 2-deoxy-4-seleno-D-furanose and a Pummerer-type base condensation as key steps. 4'-Selenothymidine was discovered to adopt the same 2'-endo/3'-exo conformation as thymidine, which is unusual in that 4'-selenouridine has the opposite conformation to that of uridine.

      Yoon, N. M.; Gyoung, Y. S. Reaction of diisobutylaluminum hydride with selected organic compounds containing representative functional groups J. Org. Chem. 1985, 50, 2443– 2450 DOI: 10.1021/jo00214a009
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      65
      Reaction of diisobutylaluminum hydride with selected organic compounds containing representative functional groups
      Yoon, Nung Min; Gyoung, Young Soo
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1985), 50 (14), 2443-50CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
      The approx. rates and stoichiometry of the reaction of excess (Me2CHCH2)2AlH (DIBAH) with 69 selected org. compds. contg. representative functional groups were examd. under standardized conditions (PhMe, 0°) in order to compare its reducing characteristics with AlH3 (previously examd.) and to enlarge the scope of its applicability as a reducing agent. Primary, secondary and tertiary alcs., simple phenols, and thiols evolve H rapidly and quant. However, DIBAH reacts with only 1 active H in primary amines. Aldehydes and ketones of diverse structure are reduced rapidly and quant. to the corresponding alcs. Redn. of norcamphor gives 7% exo- and 93% endo-norborneol. Conjugated aldehyde and ketones such as PhCH:CHCHO, MeCOCH:CH2 and isophorone are reduced rapidly and cleanly to the corresponding allylic alcs. Anthraquinone is mainly reduced to 9,10-dihydro-9,10-anthracenediol. RCO2H (R = Bu, Ph, MeCH:CH) liberate H rapidly, but only partially and very slowly. The acid chlorides and esters tested are all reduced rapidly and quant. to the corresponding alcs. Alkyl halides, such as n-octyl iodide, and arom. halides, such as p-BrC6H4Me, are all inert toward this reagent. However, epoxides are reduced rapidly with an uptake of 1 equiv of hydride. Styrene oxide is reduced to give 27% 1- and 73% 2-phenylethanol. Tertiary amides are reduced rapidly in 0.5 h, whereas primary amides are reduced only very slowly. Nitriles consume 1 equiv of hydride rapidly, but further hydride uptake is very sluggish. Nitro compds., PhN:NPh and PhN(O):NPh were reduced moderately. Cyclohexanone oxime liberates H rapidly, consuming 1.2 equiv of hydride for redn. However, further redn. is very slow. PhNCO is rapidly reduced to the imine stage. Pyridine reacts at a moderate rate with an uptake of 1 hydride over 12 h; however, further reaction is very slow. Disulfides are reduced rapidly, whereas sulfides, sulfones and sulfonic acids are inert to BIBAH under these reaction conditions. Me2SO is reduced at a moderate rate. n-Octyl tosylate is reduced quant. to n-octane within 0.5 h at 0°, whereas cyclohexyl tosylate undergoes elimination, liberating 1 equiv H rapidly to give 95% cyclohexene.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2MXktlOmsLs%253D&md5=be73b503a429a3c93356f8f306e1384b
    66. 66
      Tsang, D. S.; Yang, S.; Alphonse, F. A.; Yudin, A. K. Stereoselective isomerisation of N-allyl aziridines into geometrically stable Z enamines by using rhodium hydride catalysis Chem. - Eur. J. 2008, 14, 886– 894 DOI: 10.1002/chem.200701322
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      66
      Stereoselective isomerization of N-allyl aziridines into geometrically stable Z enamines by using rhodium hydride catalysis
      Tsang, Derek S.; Yang, Sharon; Alphonse, France-Aimee; Yudin, Andrei K.
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2008), 14 (3), 886-894CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      In the presence of rhodium(I) hydride catalysts, tertiary N-allylamines are known to isomerize into E enamines. In contrast, we have recently found that N-allylaziridines isomerize to form Z enamines. On the basis of literature data, the most likely mechanism of isomerization would involve a rhodium hydride addn./β-hydride elimination sequence. We show that the obsd. selectivity cannot be adequately explained by this pathway and is more consistent with initial CH-activation followed by rearrangement to form a five-membered cyclometallated rhodium intermediate. This intermediate subsequently undergoes reductive elimination to form a C-H bond. The resulting geometrically stable Z enamines are useful building blocks for stereoselective synthesis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXkvFaqu7w%253D&md5=d492d3d1d67528f4ed2a8904f8f16af2
    67. 67
      Burgess, K.; Ohlmeyer, M. J. Manipulation of substrate-controlled diastereoselectivities in hydroborations of acyclic allylamine derivatives J. Org. Chem. 1991, 56, 1027– 1036 DOI: 10.1021/jo00003a024
      [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

    72. 72
      Dumbre, S.; Derouaux, A.; Lescrinier, E.; Piette, A.; Joris, B.; Terrak, M.; Herdewijn, P. Synthesis of modified peptidoglycan precursor analogues for the inhibition of glycosyltransferase J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 9343– 9351 DOI: 10.1021/ja302099u
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      72
      Synthesis of Modified Peptidoglycan Precursor Analogues for the Inhibition of Glycosyltransferase
      Dumbre, Shrinivas; Derouaux, Adeline; Lescrinier, Eveline; Piette, Andre; Joris, Bernard; Terrak, Mohammed; Herdewijn, Piet
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (22), 9343-9351CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The peptidoglycan glycosyltransferases (GTs) are essential enzymes that catalyze the polymn. of glycan chains of the bacterial cell wall from lipid II and thus constitute a validated antibacterial target. Their enzymic cavity is composed of a donor site for the growing glycan chain (where the inhibitor moenomycin binds) and an acceptor site for lipid II substrate. In order to find lead inhibitors able to fill this large active site, we have synthesized a series of substrate analogs of lipid I and lipid II with variations in the lipid, the pyrophosphate, and the peptide moieties and evaluated their biol. effect on the GT activity of E. coli PBP1b and their antibacterial potential. We found several compds. able to inhibit the GT activity in vitro and cause growth defect in Bacillus subtilis. The more active was C16-phosphoglycerate-MurNAc-(l-Ala-d-Glu)-GlcNAc, which also showed antibacterial activity. These mols. are promising leads for the design of new antibacterial GT inhibitors.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XmsVWnsLY%253D&md5=36f537768aa960a62f971e0dd1a9d0c3

      79
      Phosphonium-iodonium ylides in nucleophilic substitution reactions
      Matveeva, E. D.; Podrugina, T. A.; Grishin, Yu. K.; Pavlova, A. S.; Zefirov, N. S.
      Russian Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 43 (2), 201-206CODEN: RJOCEQ; ISSN:1070-4280. (Pleiades Publishing, Ltd.)
      The prepn. and properties of mixed phosphonium-iodonium ylides [Ph3P:C(R)I+Ph][BF4] (R = CO2Et, CO2Me, CN) were studied, and the compds. were found to be capable of behaving as O-nucleophiles in nucleophilic substitution reactions (alkylation, silylation, acylation; e.g. 100 % [(TMSO)(EtO)C:CClPPh3]BF4 was obtained from [Ph3P:C(CO2Et)I+Ph][BF4]) and TMSCl.

      McMurry, J. E.; Dushin, R. G. Total synthesis of (±)-crassin by titanium-induced pinacol coupling J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1989, 111, 8928– 8929 DOI: 10.1021/ja00206a031
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      81
      Total synthesis of (±)-crassin by titanium-induced pinacol coupling
      McMurry, John E.; Dushin, R. G.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1989), 111 (24), 8928-9CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      Key steps in the synthesis of the antitumor cembrane lactone crassin (I) are the Ti-induced pinacol coupling of lactone keto aldehyde II to yield dihydroxy lactone III (R = α-OH) and the double stereochem. inversion of III (R = α-OH) to yield III (R = β-OH). Translactonization and methylenation then complete the synthesis. The synthesis demonstrates a potentially important extension of the Ti-induced carbonyl coupling reaction by showing that complex, polyoxygenated macrocycles can be produced.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXmtlehtbs%253D&md5=6f587095979fbb7ced23782d57282de6

      1. 1
        Angata, T.; Varki, A. Chemical diversity in the sialic acids and related alpha-keto acids: an evolutionary perspective Chem. Rev. 2002, 102, 439– 469 DOI: 10.1021/cr000407m
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Chemical Diversity in the Sialic Acids and Related α-Keto Acids: An Evolutionary Perspective
        Angata, Takashi; Varki, Ajit
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, D. C.) (2002), 102 (2), 439-469CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review with refs. on the evolutionary perspective, occurrence, biosynthesis, and structural diversity of sialic acids in bacteria and natural proteins.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XhtFansg%253D%253D&md5=6668c144c9fa363819c4054260265d77
      2. 2
        Varki, A. Glycan-based interactions involving vertebrate sialic-acid-recognizing proteins Nature 2007, 446, 1023– 1029 DOI: 10.1038/nature05816
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Glycan-based interactions involving vertebrate sialic-acid-recognizing proteins
        Varki, Ajit
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2007), 446 (7139), 1023-1029CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. All cells in nature are covered by a dense and complex array of carbohydrates. Given their prominence on cell surfaces, it is not surprising that these glycans mediate and/or modulate many cellular interactions. Proteins that bind sialic acid, a sugar that is found on the surface of the cell and on secreted proteins in vertebrates, are involved in a broad range of biol. processes, including intercellular adhesion, signaling and microbial attachment. Studying the roles of such proteins in vertebrates has improved our understanding of normal physiol., disease and human evolution.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXksFersr8%253D&md5=1695b2dc782f39d76ea0039a118ffaa2
      3. 3
        Severi, E.; Hood, D. W.; Thomas, G. H. Sialic acid utilization by bacterial pathogens Microbiology 2007, 153, 2817– 2822 DOI: 10.1099/mic.0.2007/009480-0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        Sialic acid utilization by bacterial pathogens
        Severi, Emmanuele; Hood, Derek W.; Thomas, Gavin H.
        Microbiology (Reading, United Kingdom) (2007), 153 (9), 2817-2822CODEN: MROBEO; ISSN:1350-0872. (Society for General Microbiology)
        A review. Sialic acid occupies the terminal position within glycan mols. on the surfaces of many vertebrate cells, where it functions in diverse cellular processes such as intercellular adhesion and cell signaling. Pathogenic bacteria have evolved to use this mol. beneficially in at least two different ways: they can coat themselves in sialic acid, providing resistance to components of the host's innate immune response, or they can use it as a nutrient. Sialic acid itself is either synthesized de novo by these bacteria or scavenged directly from the host. In this mini-review the authors will summarize recent findings relating to sialic acid transport, modification of sialic acid by O-acetylation, and the mechanisms of sialic acid-mediated complement resistance.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtFKrt7bL&md5=dc48dc4750e7b5eb1a405da6ccf288e1
      4. 4
        Varki, N. M.; Varki, A. Diversity in cell surface sialic acid presentations: implications for biology and disease Lab. Invest. 2007, 87, 851– 857 DOI: 10.1038/labinvest.3700656
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4
        Diversity in cell surface sialic acid presentations: implications for biology and disease
        Varki, Nissi M.; Varki, Ajit
        Laboratory Investigation (2007), 87 (9), 851-857CODEN: LAINAW; ISSN:0023-6837. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. Sialic acids (Sias) are typically found as terminal monosaccharides attached to cell surface glycoconjugates. They play many important roles in many physiol. and pathol. processes, including microbe binding that leads to infections, regulation of the immune response, the progression and spread of human malignancies and in certain aspects of human evolution. This review will provide some examples of these diverse roles of Sias and briefly address immunohistochem. approaches to their detection.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXptFensbg%253D&md5=a36aef1b2b057aec45c6cbe61f35024e
      5. 5
        Harduin-Lepers, A.; Krzewinski-Recchi, M. A.; Colomb, F.; Foulquier, F.; Groux-Degroote, S.; Delannoy, P. Sialyltransferases functions in cancers Front. Biosci., Elite Ed. 2012, 4, 499– 515 DOI: 10.2741/E396
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Sialytransferases functions in cancers
        Harduin-Lepers, Anne; Krzewinski-Recchi, Marie-Ange; Colomb, Florent; Foulquier, Francois; Groux-Degroote, Sophie; Delannoy, Philippe
        Frontiers in Bioscience, Elite Edition (2012), E4 (1), 499-515CODEN: FBEEAS; ISSN:1945-0508. (Frontiers in Bioscience)
        A review. Abnormally elevated levels of sialylated tumor assocd. carbohydrate antigens are frequently described at the surface of cancer cells and/or secreted in biol. fluids. It is now well established that this over-expression may result from deregulation in sialyltransferases enzymic activity involved in their biosynthesis, but the precise mol. mechanisms remain unknown. Twenty different human sialyltransferases preside to the sialylation of glycoconjugates, either glycolipids or glycoproteins. This review summarizes the current knowledge on human sialyltransferases implicated in the altered expression of sialylated tumor assocd. antigens, the mol. basis of their regulated expression in cancer cells and the various tools developed by researchers and clinicians for their study in pathol. samples.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XjsVyksbo%253D&md5=e9703de741412e4de32dacfea2753062
      6. 6
        Dall Olio, F.; Malagolini, N.; di Stefano, G.; Minni, F.; Marrano, D.; Serafini-Cessi, F. Increased CMP-NeuAc:Gal beta 1,4GlcNAc-R alpha 2,6 sialyltransferase activity in human colorectal cancer tissues Int. J. Cancer 1989, 44, 434– 439 DOI: 10.1002/ijc.2910440309
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6
        Increased CMP-NeuAc:Gal beta 1,4GlcNAc-R alpha 2,6 sialyltransferase activity in human colorectal cancer tissues
        Dall'Olio F; Malagolini N; di Stefano G; Minni F; Marrano D; Serafini-Cessi F
        International journal of cancer (1989), 44 (3), 434-9 ISSN:0020-7136.
        The sialyltransferase activities of 10 human colorectal specimens were compared with those of the corresponding adjacent normal mucosa. Using asialofetuin as an acceptor we found, in tumor tissues of 9 out of 10 patients, an increased sialyltransferase activity towards the N-linked chains as determined upon peptide-N4-(N-acetyl-beta-glucosaminyl)asparagine amidase (PNGase) treatment. On the contrary, the activity towards the O-linked chains was not significantly changed. When the specificity of the sialyltransferase acting on N-linked chains was investigated by using N-acetyl-lactosamine (Gal beta 1,4GlcNAc) as an acceptor, we found that the alpha 2,6 sialyltransferase activity expressed by both normal and tumor colorectal tissues was far higher than the alpha 2,3-activity and that alpha 2,6 was the only sialyltransferase activity increased in tumor tissues. Kinetic analysis revealed that normal and tumor alpha 2,6 sialyltransferases have the same apparent Km for the acceptor substrate (469 and 465 microns), but normal enzyme has a higher Km for CMP-NeuAc (303 microns) than the tumor enzyme (50 microns). The higher affinity of tumor enzyme for the nucleotide-sugar might partially explain its increased activity in tumor tissues. In addition, tumor tissues contain a lower amount of sialic acid despite the increase in alpha 2,6 sialyltransferase activity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaL1MznvFCnsg%253D%253D&md5=77de5127f71abb44960ecd1f02e015fd
      7. 7
        Yamamoto, H.; Saito, T.; Kaneko, Y.; Kersey, D.; Yong, V. W.; Bremer, E. G.; Mkrdichian, E.; Cerullo, L.; Leestma, J.; Moskal, J. R. alpha2,3-sialyltransferase mRNA and alpha2,3-linked glycoprotein sialylation are increased in malignant gliomas Brain Res. 1997, 755, 175– 179 DOI: 10.1016/S0006-8993(97)00241-2
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        α2,3-Sialyltransferase mRNA and α2,3-linked glycoprotein sialylation are increased in malignant gliomas
        Yamamoto, Hirotaka; Saito, Tasuku; Kaneko, Yoichi; Kersey, Donna; Yong, Voon Wee; Bremer, Eric G.; Mkrdichian, Edward; Cerullo, Leonard; Leestma, Jan; Moskal, Joseph R.
        Brain Research (1997), 755 (1), 175-179CODEN: BRREAP; ISSN:0006-8993. (Elsevier)
        CMP-NeuAc:Galβ1,3(4)GlcNAc α2,3-sialyltransferase (α2,3-ST) mRNA was expressed in human glioma specimens, human fetal astrocytes, and a panel of brain tumor cell lines. Maackia amurensis agglutinin staining revealed the presence of α2,3-linked sialic acids on glioma cell surfaces and extracellular matrixes whereas normal human adult astrocytes were neg. Increased expression of α2,3-linked glycoprotein sialylation may play a role in glial tumorigenesis.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXisVems7w%253D&md5=12e827634312e5b74e973f3978378f77
      8. 8
        Burchell, J.; Poulsom, R.; Hanby, A.; Whitehouse, C.; Cooper, L.; Clausen, H.; Miles, D.; Taylor-Papadimitriou, J. An alpha2,3 sialyltransferase (ST3Gal I) is elevated in primary breast carcinomas Glycobiology 1999, 9, 1307– 1311 DOI: 10.1093/glycob/9.12.1307
        [Crossref], Google Scholar

      9. 9
        Wang, P. H.; Li, Y. F.; Juang, C. M.; Lee, Y. R.; Chao, H. T.; Tsai, Y. C.; Yuan, C. C. Altered mRNA expression of sialyltransferase in squamous cell carcinomas of the cervix Gynecol. Oncol. 2001, 83, 121– 127 DOI: 10.1006/gyno.2001.6358
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        Altered mRNA expression of sialyltransferase in squamous cell carcinomas of the cervix
        Wang, Peng-Hui; Li, Ywan Feng; Juang, Chi-Mou; Lee, Yan-Ru; Chao, Hsiang-Tai; Tsai, Ying-Chieh; Yuan, Chiou-Chung
        Gynecologic Oncology (2001), 83 (1), 121-127CODEN: GYNOA3; ISSN:0090-8258. (Academic Press)
        Increased sialylation has been reported in various kinds of cancers, but to date, sialylation of cervical carcinoma has never been evaluated. This study of the changes in mRNA (mRNA) expression of the four sialyltransferases (ST3Gal I, ST3Gal III, ST3Gal IV, and ST6Gal I) in a normal cervix and that with FIGO stage IB1 squamous cell carcinoma was undertaken to assess the extent of sialylation assocd. with establishment of the carcinoma. Alterations in ST mRNA expression in FIGO IB1 cervical cancer (n = 30) and normal cervixes (n = 30) were examd. by semiquant. reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).Results. ST6Gal I expression was enhanced in squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix (P = 0.026, Mann-Whitney U test), but mRNA expression from the other three STs (ST3Gal I, ST3Gal III, and ST3Gal IV) was significantly down-expressed in squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix compared to the normal cervix (P = 0.003, P < 0.001, and P = 0.001, resp.). High ST6Gal I expression was assocd. with more invasive properties of cervical cancer, such as deep stromal invasion, lymph or vascular space involvement, and poor differentiation (P = 0.010, P < 0.001, P < 0.001, resp.). A combination of enhanced ST6Gal I mRNA expression and decreased mRNA expression from ST3Gal I, ST3Gal III, and ST3Gal IV might be important in cervical cancer. Future studies will investigate whether RT-PCR detection of the expression of these enzymes can be helpful for prognostic purposes. (c) 2001 Academic Press.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXnt1emur4%253D&md5=372ae654f29110608777bac9765873d2

        Wang, X.; Zhang, L.-H.; Ye, X.-S. Recent development in the design of sialyltransferase inhibitors Med. Res. Rev. 2003, 23, 32– 47 DOI: 10.1002/med.10030
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13
        Recent development in the design of sialyltransferase inhibitors
        Wang, Xiaofang; Zhang, Li-He; Ye, Xin-Shan
        Medicinal Research Reviews (2003), 23 (1), 32-47CODEN: MRREDD; ISSN:0198-6325. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        A review. Sialylation at the non-reducing end of glycoconjugates is an important biol. process in cellular recognitions, tumor metastases, and immune responses, which are mediated by a family of enzymes known as sialytransferases. Inhibition of sialytransferases may prove useful in elucidating the biol. functions of sialylation and may have therapeutic applications. This review summarizes the recent development in this field with particular focus on the strategies used for the design of carbohydrate mimetics and the structure-activity relationships of substrate-based sialytransferase inhibitors.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXisFCrsQ%253D%253D&md5=5e2f33bc5dd4b04d6fbc0ded658ad145

      15. 15
        Jung, K.-H.; Schwörer, R.; Schmidt, R. R. Sialyltransferase Inhibitors Trends Glycosci. Glycotechnol. 2003, 15, 275– 289 DOI: 10.4052/tigg.15.275

        15
        Sialyltransferase inhibitors
        Jung, Karl-Heinz; Schwoerer, Ralf; Schmidt, Richard R.
        Trends in Glycoscience and Glycotechnology (2003), 15 (85), 275-289CODEN: TGGLEE; ISSN:0915-7352. (FCCA)
        A review. Sialylation of glycoproteins and glycolipids plays an important role in many cell surface processes; of special interest in this context are changes in tissue involved in diseases and esp. changes during infections. Therefore, inhibitors of sialyltransferases regulating sialylation might be of medicinal interest, esp. in the therapy of virus and cancer diseases. The present paper reviews the development of sialyltransferase inhibitors; thus acceptor analogs, donor analogs, transition-state analogs, and bisubstrate analogs were designed based on sialic acid derivs. as well as on structural mimetics. This way, very potent sialyltransferase inhibitors with inhibition consts. in the low nanomolar range have been recently found.

      21. 21
        Kumar, R.; Nasi, R.; Bhasin, M.; Huan Khieu, N.; Hsieh, M.; Gilbert, M.; Jarrell, H.; Zou, W.; Jennings, H. J. Sialyltransferase inhibitors: consideration of molecular shape and charge/hydrophobic interactions Carbohydr. Res. 2013, 378, 45– 55 DOI: 10.1016/j.carres.2012.12.017
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        Sialyltransferase inhibitors: consideration of molecular shape and charge/hydrophobic interactions
        Kumar, Rishi; Nasi, Ravindranath; Bhasin, Milan; Huan Khieu, Nam; Hsieh, Margaret; Gilbert, Michel; Jarrell, Harold; Zou, Wei; Jennings, Harold J.
        Carbohydrate Research (2013), 378 (), 45-55CODEN: CRBRAT; ISSN:0008-6215. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        In order to evaluate the importance of mol. shape of inhibitor mols. and the charge/H-bond and hydrophobic interactions, we synthesized three types of mols. and tested them against a sialyltransferase. The first type of compds. were designed as substrate mimics in which the phosphate in CMP-Neu5NAc was replaced by a non-hydrolysable, uncharged 1,2,3-triazole moiety. The second type of compd. contained a 2-deoxy-2,3-dehydro-acetylneuraminic moiety which was linked to cytidine through its carboxylic acid and amide linkers. In the third type of compd. the sialyl phosphate was substituted by an aryl sulfonamide which was then linked to cytidine. Inhibition study of these cytidine conjugates against Campylobacter jejuni sialyltransferase Cst 06 showed that the first type of mols. are competitive inhibitors, whereas the other two could only inhibit the enzyme non-competitively. The results indicate that although the binding specificity may be guided by mol. shape and H-bond interaction, the charge and hydrophobic interactions contributed most to the binding affinity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvVGgsrw%253D&md5=edf1451dbe3f6e55ada834dff0f0741b

        Hinou, H.; Sun, X. L.; Ito, Y. Systematic syntheses and inhibitory activities of bisubstrate-type inhibitors of sialyltransferases J. Org. Chem. 2003, 68, 5602– 5613 DOI: 10.1021/jo030042g

        28
        Systematic Syntheses and Inhibitory Activities of Bisubstrate-Type Inhibitors of Sialyltransferases
        Hinou, Hiroshi; Sun, Xue-Long; Ito, Yukishige
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2003), 68 (14), 5602-5613CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        Bisubstrate-type sialyltransferase inhibitors, having CMP-NeuAc and N-acetyllactosamine (or lactose) moieties connected by an alkanedithiol linker, were synthesized systematically. A uniform synthetic strategy was adopted that consists of consecutive couplings of three components (N-acetyllactosamine or lactose, sialic acid, and CMP), followed by oxidn. Due to the sensitivity of the compds. under alk. conditions, final deprotection required careful monitoring by 1H NMR. The inhibitory activities toward ST6N and ST3N indicated that both the structure of the acceptor moiety and the distance between donor and acceptor moieties were important.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXksFWjsrY%253D&md5=c5917aa2c9308cd7f8ac2f484b15395f
      29. 29
        Izumi, M.; Wada, K.; Yuasa, H.; Hashimoto, H. Synthesis of bisubstrate and donor analogues of sialyltransferase and their inhibitory activities J. Org. Chem. 2005, 70, 8817– 8824 DOI: 10.1021/jo0512608
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29
        Synthesis of Bisubstrate and Donor Analogues of Sialyltransferase and Their Inhibitory Activities
        Izumi, Masayuki; Wada, Katsuhiro; Yuasa, Hideya; Hashimoto, Hironobu
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2005), 70 (22), 8817-8824CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        Sialyltransferases (STs) are involved in the biosynthesis of glycoconjugates with important biol. activities. Most STs utilize cytidine-5'-monophospho-N-acetylneuraminic acid (CMP-Neu5Ac) as a common donor substrate. A bisubstrate analog contg. the donor substrate (CMP-Neu5Ac mimic) and the acceptor substrate (galactose) was synthesized. Four donor analogs having the partial structure of the bisubstrate analog were also synthesized to support study of the structure-activity relationship. Each analog contains an ethylene group in place of the exocyclic anomeric oxygen of CMP-Neu5Ac. The bisubstrate analog exhibited only weak inhibitory activity to rat recombinant α-2,3- and α-2,6-ST (IC50 = 1.3, 2.4 mM). Conversion of the C-1 carboxylate of the Neu5Ac moiety to carboxyamide, hydroxymethyl, or methylene phosphate each resulted in a redn. in inhibitory activity. Among the synthesized analogs, cytidin-5'-yl sialylethylphosphonate (4) was the most potent inhibitor against rat recombinant α-2,3- and α-2,6-ST (IC50 = 0.047, 0.34 mM).
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Schaub, C.; Müller, B.; Schmidt, R. R. New sialyltransferase inhibitors based on CMP-quinic acid: development of a new sialyltransferase assay Glycoconjugate J. 1998, 15, 345– 354 DOI: 10.1023/A:1006917717161
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        New sialyltransferase inhibitors based on CMP-quinic acid: development of a new sialyltransferase assay
        Schaub, Christoph; Muller, Bernd; Schmidt, Richard R.
        Glycoconjugate Journal (1998), 15 (4), 345-354CODEN: GLJOEW; ISSN:0282-0080. (Chapman & Hall)
        Quinic acid was transformed into phosphitamides which could be readily linked to a 5'-O-unprotected cytidine deriv.; ensuing oxidn. of the obtained phosphite triesters with tert-Bu hydroperoxide furnished the corresponding phosphate triesters. Hydrogenolytic debenzylation of the phosphate moiety, base catalyzed removal of acetyl protective groups, and basic hydrolysis of the Me ester of the quinic acid moiety furnished CMP-Neu5Ac analogs I [R = OH, R1 = H; R = H, R1 = NH= NH2, NHAc]. In order to measure their inhibition of sialyltransferases, a nonradioactive sialyltransferase assay [employed for a(2-6)-sialyltransferase from rat liver (EC 2.4.99.1)] based on reversed-phase HPLC sepn. of UV-labeled acceptor (p-nitrophenyl glycoside of N-acetyllactosamine) from the UV-labeled product (p-nitrophenyl glycoside of sialyl a(2-6')-N-acetyllactosamine) and p-nitrophenylalanine as internal std. was developed. The assay reproduced the reported KM values for CMP-Neu5Ac and N-acetyllactosamine and the K1 values for CDP. I [R = OH, R1 = H; R = H, R1 = NHAc] turned out to be potent sialyltransferase inhibitors.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXivV2htrs%253D&md5=4fa8f26c6eac9c8c6f8a161e7ada8c12

        Amann, F.; Schaub, C.; Müller, B.; Schmidt, R. R. New potent sialyltransferase inhibitors—synthesis of donor and of transition-state analogues of sialyl donor CMP-Neu5Ac Chem. - Eur. J. 1998, 4, 1106– 1115 DOI: 10.1002/(SICI)1521-3765(19980615)4:6<1106::AID-CHEM1106>3.0.CO;2-7
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        31
        New potent sialyltransferase inhibitors - synthesis of donor and of transition-state analogs of sialyl donor CMP-Neu5Ac
        Amann, Franz; Schaub, Christoph; Muller, Bernd; Schmidt, Richard R.
        Chemistry--A European Journal (1998), 4 (6), 1106-1115CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        Enzymic sialyl transfer with CMP-Neu5Ac as donor can be inhibited by CDP. Therefore sialyl nucleotide phosphonates were synthesized as substrate analogs. With α(2-6)-sialyltransferase from rat liver (EC.2.4.99.1) only moderate inhibition was found for these compds. In order to obtain transition-state analogs of CMP-Neu5Ac different linkages between 2,3-dehydro-N-acetylneuraminol and CMP were generated. Compd. I exhibited excellent α(2-6)-sialyltransferase inhibition in the nanomolar range (Ki = 350 nM), resulting in a 130-fold higher affinity for the enzyme than CMP-Neu5Ac (KM = 46 μM).

      35. 35
        Schwörer, R.; Schmidt, R. R. Efficient sialyltransferase inhibitors based on glycosides of N-acetylglucosamine J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2002, 124, 1632– 1637 DOI: 10.1021/ja017370n
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35
        Efficient sialyltransferase inhibitors based on glycosides of N-acetylglucosamine
        Schworer Ralf; Schmidt Richard R
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (8), 1632-7 ISSN:0002-7863.
        D-Glucosamine was transformed into phenyl and 2-benzoyloxyethyl N-acetylglucosamine beta-glycosides 6a and 6b, respectively. Transformation of 6a,b into 6-O-unprotected N-acetylglucosamine derivatives 9a,b permitted the generation of an aldehyde group in the 6-position. Treatment of these intermediates with base afforded unsaturated aldehyde derivatives 10a,b, which are structural mimics of 2,3-dehydroneuraminic acid. H-Phosphonate addition to the aldehyde group and attachment of the cytidine monophosphate residue to the generated hydroxy group gave fully protected transition state analogues of cytidine monophosphate-N-acetylneuraminic acid 14a,b. Liberation of the unprotected compounds 1ah,l and 1bh,l led to excellent inhibitors of alpha(2-6)-sialyltransferase from rat liver. Variation of the protective group cleavage procedure for 14a,b led to formal loss of phosphate, thus resulting in diene derivatives (E)-/(Z)-2a,b, which also exhibited inhibitory properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD387ltlWnsQ%253D%253D&md5=9618a971de63256a565c91e0b1a11bb5
      36. 36
        Skropeta, D.; Schwörer, R.; Haag, T.; Schmidt, R. R. Asymmetric synthesis and affinity of potent sialyltransferase inhibitors based on transition-state analogues Glycoconjugate J. 2004, 21, 205– 219 DOI: 10.1023/B:GLYC.0000045093.96413.62
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Asymmetric synthesis and affinity of potent sialyltransferase inhibitors based on transition-state analogs
        Skropeta, Danielle; Schwoerer, Ralf; Haag, Tobias; Schmidt, Richard R.
        Glycoconjugate Journal (2004), 21 (5), 205-219CODEN: GLJOEW; ISSN:0282-0080. (Kluwer Academic Publishers)
        Inhibitors that are structurally related to the transition-state model of the proposed SN1-type mechanism of sialyl transfer, exhibit particularly high binding affinities to α(2-6)sialyltransferases. Furthermore, replacing the neuraminyl residue with a simple aryl or heteroaryl ring and substituting the carboxylate group for a phosphonate moiety, improves both binding affinity and synthetic accessibility. Reported was the synthesis and inhibition of a wide range of novel, potent transition-state analog based α(2-6)sialyltransferase inhibitors comprising a planar anomeric carbon, an increased distance between the anomeric carbon and the CMP leaving group, and at least two neg. charges. Also presented was a short, efficient asym. synthesis of the most promising benzyl inhibitors, providing rapid access to large quantities of highly potent, stereochem.-pure (>96% de) inhibitors for further biol. investigation (e.g. the trisodium salt of (R)-I, Ki = 70 nM).
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      42. 42
        Pauling, L. Molecular architecture and biological reactions Chem. Eng. News 1946, 24, 1375– 1377 DOI: 10.1021/cen-v024n010.p1375
