        42
        Molecular architecture and biological reactions
        Pauling, Linus
        Chemical & Engineering News (1946), 24 (), 1375-7CODEN: CENEAR; ISSN:0009-2347.
        Answers to many basic problems of biology, such as nature of growth, mechanism of duplication of viruses and genes, action of enzymes, mechanism of physiol. activity of drugs, hormones and vitamins, and structure and action of nerve and brain tissue, may lie in knowledge of mol. structure and intermol. reactions gained by further probing into the dimensional range of approx. 10-100 A. The importance of shape as exemplified in the concept of complementariness of surface structures of antigen and antibody and other forms of biol. specificity is discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaH28XisVSlsA%253D%253D&md5=0d971f72bf49f07a45b8a8607b7eb725

      45. 45
        Heasley, B. Recent developments in the stereocontrolled synthesis of highly substituted cyclopentane core structures: from drug discovery research to natural product synthesis Curr. Org. Chem. 2014, 18, 641– 686 DOI: 10.2174/13852728113176660150
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        45
        Recent Developments in the Stereocontrolled Synthesis of Highly Substituted Cyclopentane Core Structures: From Drug Discovery Research to Natural Product Synthesis
        Heasley, Brian
        Current Organic Chemistry (2014), 18 (6), 641-686CODEN: CORCFE; ISSN:1385-2728. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
        A review. The cyclopentane motif has been utilized as an effective core scaffold for several highly successful medicinal chem. programs and, thus, has provided an under appreciated yet significant value for biomedical research. Moreover, the modern synthetic methods highlighted in this work offer a wealth of attractive and accessible technologies for the stereocontrolled construction of exceedingly complex cyclopentanoid chemotypes of natural and unnatural origin. It is contended that the cyclopentane framework should be regarded as a privileged scaffold for drug discovery research and that expanded screening campaigns of novel cyclopentane-based small mol. libraries for therapeutically relevant biol. properties will have a favorable impact on the development of the active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) of tomorrow.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      48. 48
        Shetty, A. K.; Peek, L. A. Peramivir for the treatment of influenza Expert Rev. Anti-Infect. Ther. 2012, 10, 123– 143 DOI: 10.1586/eri.11.174
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48
        Peramivir for the treatment of influenza
        Shetty, Avinash K.; Peek, Leigh A.
        Expert Review of Anti-Infective Therapy (2012), 10 (2), 123-143CODEN: ERATCK; ISSN:1478-7210. (Expert Reviews Ltd.)
        A review. Peramivir (BioCryst Pharmaceuticals) is a novel investigational i.v. neuraminidase inhibitor that exhibits potent antiviral activity against influenza A and B viruses. Peramivir is created by a structure-based drug design and consists of a cyclopentane backbone with a pos. charged guanidinyl group and lipophilic side chains. Peramivir was made available in the USA through the Emergency Investigational New Drug regulations and under an Emergency Use Authorization for hospitalized patients with known or suspected influenza during the 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic. In trials involving ambulatory adult subjects, i.v. peramivir is safe and has a pharmacokinetic profile that supports once-daily dosing. The drug is licensed in Japan and South Korea and is currently undergoing Phase III trials in the USA. Viral resistance mechanisms to peramivir have not been fully delineated and ongoing surveillance is important. Given the serious health threat of influenza at all ages and limitations in vaccine delivery, peramivir is a promising addn. to the currently limited treatment options for the treatment of severe influenza infection.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XisVKhur8%253D&md5=0d07fd0d34d1249ec1a84c16f235b6fe

        55
        Reaction of methyl-4-methylene-2,3-O-isopropylidene-β-D-ribofuranoside with N-bromosuccinimide in aqueous tetrahydrofuran
        Ivanova, N. A.; Valiullina, Z. R.; Shitikova, O. V.; Miftakhov, M. S.
        Russian Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 43 (5), 742-746CODEN: RJOCEQ; ISSN:1070-4280. (Pleiades Publishing, Ltd.)
        Methyl-4-methylene-2,3-O-isopropylidene-β-D-ribofuranoside prepd. from D-ribose reacted in a system NBS-THF-H2O to give a mixt. of stereoisomeric products of regioselective bromohydroxylation of a double bond. The reaction involved a hydrolysis of the glycoside bond, but the acetonide protective group was retained. The mechanism of the selective hydrolysis originating from the ring-chain tautomerism of bromohydrins obtained was proved by the 1H NMR spectra of the steroisomeric methyl-5-deoxy-5-bromo-4-hydroxy-2,3-O-isopropylidene-β-D-ribofuranosides. By crotonic cyclization of the formed masked 1,4-dicarbonyl compds. at heating in benzene in the presence of neutral Al2O3 a new chiral cyclopentenone block, 2-bromo-4,5-isopropylideneoxycyclopent-2-en-1-one, was obtained in a low yield.

        Denmark, S. E.; Forbes, D. C.; Hays, D. S.; DePue, J. S.; Wilde, R. G. Catalytic epoxidation of alkenes with oxone J. Org. Chem. 1995, 60, 1391– 1407 DOI: 10.1021/jo00110a049
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        57
        Catalytic Epoxidation of Alkenes with Oxone
        Denmark, Scott E.; Forbes, David C.; Hays, David S.; DePue, Jeffrey S.; Wilde, Richard G.
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (1995), 60 (5), 1391-407CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        A practical, general and efficient protocol for the catalytic epoxidn. of alkenes has been developed. The in situ generation of reactive dioxiranes capable of epoxidizing a variety of alkenes under biphasic conditions has been accomplished using phase transfer catalysts bearing a carbonyl group. Optimal epoxidn. conditions employ 10 mol% of 1-dodecyl-1-methyl-4-oxopiperidinium triflate in a CH2Cl2/pH 7.5-8.0 biphase using potassium monoperoxosulfate (Oxone) as the oxidant. Optimization of the conditions identified (1) slow addn. rate, (2) pH 7.5-8.0, (3) N-dodecyl chain, and (4) the triflate salt as key exptl. and structural variables. A selection of nine olefins was successfully oxidized to the corresponding epoxides in 83-96% yield.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXjvFOlsb0%253D&md5=ef22670f20cd13af30401a0688213750

        58
        Mixed solvents containing methanol as useful reaction media for unique chemoselective reductions within lithium borohydride
        Soai, Kenso; Ookawa, Atsuhiro
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (1986), 51 (21), 4000-5CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
        The reducing ability of LiBH4 is greatly enhanced in mixed solvents contg. methanol. Esters, lactones, and epoxides are reduced chemoselectively more rapidly with LiBH4-MeOH (1 equiv. added at the beginning)-ether than with LiBH4-ether in the presence of other reducible groups such as carboxylic acid, chloride, nitro, and carbamoyl. Nitro, nitrile, and carboxyl, and primary and tertiary amide groups are reduced with LiBH4-MeOH (4 equiv. dropwise addn.)-diglyme(or THF). However, secondary amides derived from aliph. amines and metal carboxylate are not reduced. Thus, unique chemoselective redns. of primary amide in the presence of secondary amide or metal carboxylate are achieved.

        Rosen, T.; Lico, I. M.; Chu, D. T. W. A convenient and highly chemoselective method for the reductive acetylation of azides J. Org. Chem. 1988, 53, 1580– 1582 DOI: 10.1021/jo00242a051
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        61
        A convenient and highly chemoselective method for the reductive acetylation of azides
        Rosen, Terry; Lico, Isabella M.; Chu, Daniel T. W.
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (1988), 53 (7), 1580-2CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
        Azides, e.g. I, react with AcSH to afford the corresponding acetamides, e.g. II, in good yield. The reaction is highly chemoselective. The transformation occurs under extremely mild conditions and has been accomplished in the presence of a wide variety of functional groups including tert-butoxycarbonyl and benzyl protecting groups, olefins, carboxylic esters and a methanesulfonate ester. This rapid reductive acetylation allows the introduction of a protected amino group into a mol. possessing functionality otherwise incompatible with the free amine.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXhsFShs7w%253D&md5=792396a9bdf31763f2cbced44e6ace61
      62. 62
        Kolakowski, R. V.; Shangguan, N.; Sauers, R. R.; Williams, L. J. Mechanism of thio acid/azide amidation J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 5695– 5702 DOI: 10.1021/ja057533y
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        62
        Mechanism of Thio Acid/Azide Amidation
        Kolakowski, Robert V.; Shangguan, Ning; Sauers, Ronald R.; Williams, Lawrence J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (17), 5695-5702CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A combined exptl. and computational mechanistic study of amide formation from thio acids and azides is described. The data support two distinct mechanistic pathways dependent on the electronic character of the azide component. Relatively electron-rich azides undergo bimol. coupling with thiocarboxylates via an anion-accelerated [3+2] cycloaddn. to give a thiatriazoline. Highly electron-poor azides couple via bimol. union of the terminal nitrogen of the azide with sulfur of the thiocarboxylate to give a linear adduct. Cyclization of this intermediate gives a thiatriazoline. Decompn. to amide is found to proceed via retro-[3+2] cycloaddn. of the neutral thiatriazoline intermediates. Computational anal. (DFT, 6-31+G(d)) identified pathways by which both classes of azide undergo [3+2] cycloaddn. with thio acid to give thiatriazoline intermediates, although these paths are higher in energy than the thiocarboxylate amidations. These studies also establish that the reaction profile of electron-poor azides is attributable to a prior capture mechanism followed by intramol. acylation.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xjt1yitbo%253D&md5=2b944c5e33ac52fb528626432d84aaf6

        A New DNA Building Block, 4'-Selenothymidine: Synthesis and Modification to 4'-Seleno-AZT as a Potential Anti-HIV Agent
        Alexander, Varughese; Choi, Won Jun; Chun, Jeongha; Kim, Hea Ok; Jeon, Ji Hye; Tosh, Dilip K.; Lee, Hyuk Woo; Chandra, Girish; Choi, Jungwon; Jeong, Lak Shin
        Organic Letters (2010), 12 (10), 2242-2245CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
        The first synthesis of 4'-selenothymidine, a novel DNA building block, and 4'-seleno-AZT was accomplished from 2-deoxy-D-ribose via stereoselective formation of 2-deoxy-4-seleno-D-furanose and a Pummerer-type base condensation as key steps. 4'-Selenothymidine was discovered to adopt the same 2'-endo/3'-exo conformation as thymidine, which is unusual in that 4'-selenouridine has the opposite conformation to that of uridine.

      65. 65
        Yoon, N. M.; Gyoung, Y. S. Reaction of diisobutylaluminum hydride with selected organic compounds containing representative functional groups J. Org. Chem. 1985, 50, 2443– 2450 DOI: 10.1021/jo00214a009
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        65
        Reaction of diisobutylaluminum hydride with selected organic compounds containing representative functional groups
        Yoon, Nung Min; Gyoung, Young Soo
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (1985), 50 (14), 2443-50CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
        The approx. rates and stoichiometry of the reaction of excess (Me2CHCH2)2AlH (DIBAH) with 69 selected org. compds. contg. representative functional groups were examd. under standardized conditions (PhMe, 0°) in order to compare its reducing characteristics with AlH3 (previously examd.) and to enlarge the scope of its applicability as a reducing agent. Primary, secondary and tertiary alcs., simple phenols, and thiols evolve H rapidly and quant. However, DIBAH reacts with only 1 active H in primary amines. Aldehydes and ketones of diverse structure are reduced rapidly and quant. to the corresponding alcs. Redn. of norcamphor gives 7% exo- and 93% endo-norborneol. Conjugated aldehyde and ketones such as PhCH:CHCHO, MeCOCH:CH2 and isophorone are reduced rapidly and cleanly to the corresponding allylic alcs. Anthraquinone is mainly reduced to 9,10-dihydro-9,10-anthracenediol. RCO2H (R = Bu, Ph, MeCH:CH) liberate H rapidly, but only partially and very slowly. The acid chlorides and esters tested are all reduced rapidly and quant. to the corresponding alcs. Alkyl halides, such as n-octyl iodide, and arom. halides, such as p-BrC6H4Me, are all inert toward this reagent. However, epoxides are reduced rapidly with an uptake of 1 equiv of hydride. Styrene oxide is reduced to give 27% 1- and 73% 2-phenylethanol. Tertiary amides are reduced rapidly in 0.5 h, whereas primary amides are reduced only very slowly. Nitriles consume 1 equiv of hydride rapidly, but further hydride uptake is very sluggish. Nitro compds., PhN:NPh and PhN(O):NPh were reduced moderately. Cyclohexanone oxime liberates H rapidly, consuming 1.2 equiv of hydride for redn. However, further redn. is very slow. PhNCO is rapidly reduced to the imine stage. Pyridine reacts at a moderate rate with an uptake of 1 hydride over 12 h; however, further reaction is very slow. Disulfides are reduced rapidly, whereas sulfides, sulfones and sulfonic acids are inert to BIBAH under these reaction conditions. Me2SO is reduced at a moderate rate. n-Octyl tosylate is reduced quant. to n-octane within 0.5 h at 0°, whereas cyclohexyl tosylate undergoes elimination, liberating 1 equiv H rapidly to give 95% cyclohexene.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2MXktlOmsLs%253D&md5=be73b503a429a3c93356f8f306e1384b
      66. 66
        Tsang, D. S.; Yang, S.; Alphonse, F. A.; Yudin, A. K. Stereoselective isomerisation of N-allyl aziridines into geometrically stable Z enamines by using rhodium hydride catalysis Chem. - Eur. J. 2008, 14, 886– 894 DOI: 10.1002/chem.200701322
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        66
        Stereoselective isomerization of N-allyl aziridines into geometrically stable Z enamines by using rhodium hydride catalysis
        Tsang, Derek S.; Yang, Sharon; Alphonse, France-Aimee; Yudin, Andrei K.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2008), 14 (3), 886-894CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        In the presence of rhodium(I) hydride catalysts, tertiary N-allylamines are known to isomerize into E enamines. In contrast, we have recently found that N-allylaziridines isomerize to form Z enamines. On the basis of literature data, the most likely mechanism of isomerization would involve a rhodium hydride addn./β-hydride elimination sequence. We show that the obsd. selectivity cannot be adequately explained by this pathway and is more consistent with initial CH-activation followed by rearrangement to form a five-membered cyclometallated rhodium intermediate. This intermediate subsequently undergoes reductive elimination to form a C-H bond. The resulting geometrically stable Z enamines are useful building blocks for stereoselective synthesis.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXkvFaqu7w%253D&md5=d492d3d1d67528f4ed2a8904f8f16af2

        72
        Synthesis of Modified Peptidoglycan Precursor Analogues for the Inhibition of Glycosyltransferase
        Dumbre, Shrinivas; Derouaux, Adeline; Lescrinier, Eveline; Piette, Andre; Joris, Bernard; Terrak, Mohammed; Herdewijn, Piet
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (22), 9343-9351CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The peptidoglycan glycosyltransferases (GTs) are essential enzymes that catalyze the polymn. of glycan chains of the bacterial cell wall from lipid II and thus constitute a validated antibacterial target. Their enzymic cavity is composed of a donor site for the growing glycan chain (where the inhibitor moenomycin binds) and an acceptor site for lipid II substrate. In order to find lead inhibitors able to fill this large active site, we have synthesized a series of substrate analogs of lipid I and lipid II with variations in the lipid, the pyrophosphate, and the peptide moieties and evaluated their biol. effect on the GT activity of E. coli PBP1b and their antibacterial potential. We found several compds. able to inhibit the GT activity in vitro and cause growth defect in Bacillus subtilis. The more active was C16-phosphoglycerate-MurNAc-(l-Ala-d-Glu)-GlcNAc, which also showed antibacterial activity. These mols. are promising leads for the design of new antibacterial GT inhibitors.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XmsVWnsLY%253D&md5=36f537768aa960a62f971e0dd1a9d0c3
      73. 73
        Marschner, C.; Penn, G.; Griengl, H. Synthesis of α- and β-D-carbaribofuranose from (+)-norborn-5-en-2-one Tetrahedron Lett. 1990, 31, 2873– 2874 DOI: 10.1016/0040-4039(90)80170-Q
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      74. 74
        Allevi, P.; Cribiù, R.; Anastasia, M. Facile and rapid regeneration of free amino acids from N-benzyloxycarbonyl-5-oxazolidinones and from N-benzyloxycarbonylamino derivatives by treatment with BCl3 in dichloromethane Tetrahedron Lett. 2004, 45, 5841– 5843 DOI: 10.1016/j.tetlet.2004.06.011
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      75. 75
        Bajwa, J. S. Chemoselective deprotection of benzyl esters in the presence of benzyl ethers, benzyloxymethyl ethers and n-benzyl groups by catalytic transfer hydrogenation Tetrahedron Lett. 1992, 33, 2299– 2302 DOI: 10.1016/S0040-4039(00)74195-5
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      76. 76
        Kuhn, B.; Benz, J.; Greif, M.; Engel, A. M.; Sobek, H.; Rudolph, M. G. The structure of human α-2,6-sialyltransferase reveals the binding mode of complex glycans Acta Crystallogr., Sect. D: Biol. Crystallogr. 2013, 69, 1826– 1838 DOI: 10.1107/S0907444913015412
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      77. 77
        Legaigneur, P.; Breton, C.; El Battari, A.; Guillemot, J. C.; Auge, C.; Malissard, M.; Berger, E. G.; Ronin, C. Exploring the acceptor substrate recognition of the human beta-galactoside alpha 2,6-sialyltransferase J. Biol. Chem. 2001, 276, 21608– 21617 DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M100860200
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      78. 78
        Boers, R. B.; Randulfe, Y. P.; van der Haas, H. N. S.; van Rossum-Baan, M.; Lugtenburg, J. Synthesis and spectroscopic characterization of 1–13C- and 4–13C-Plastoquinone-9 Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2002, 2002, 2094– 2108 DOI: 10.1002/1099-0690(200207)2002:13<2094::AID-EJOC2094>3.0.CO;2-E
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      79. 79
        Matveeva, E. D.; Podrugina, T. A.; Grishin, Y. K.; Pavlova, A. S.; Zefirov, N. S. Phosphonium-iodonim ylides in nucleophilic substitution reactions Russ. J. Org. Chem. 2007, 43, 201– 206 DOI: 10.1134/S107042800702008X
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        79
        Phosphonium-iodonium ylides in nucleophilic substitution reactions
        Matveeva, E. D.; Podrugina, T. A.; Grishin, Yu. K.; Pavlova, A. S.; Zefirov, N. S.
        Russian Journal of Organic Chemistry (2007), 43 (2), 201-206CODEN: RJOCEQ; ISSN:1070-4280. (Pleiades Publishing, Ltd.)
        The prepn. and properties of mixed phosphonium-iodonium ylides [Ph3P:C(R)I+Ph][BF4] (R = CO2Et, CO2Me, CN) were studied, and the compds. were found to be capable of behaving as O-nucleophiles in nucleophilic substitution reactions (alkylation, silylation, acylation; e.g. 100 % [(TMSO)(EtO)C:CClPPh3]BF4 was obtained from [Ph3P:C(CO2Et)I+Ph][BF4]) and TMSCl.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXjvFansLg%253D&md5=392370345a04c14ff301a22f54b4d078
      80. 80
        Tadano, K.; Maeda, H.; Hoshino, M.; Iimura, Y.; Suami, T. A novel transformation of four aldoses to some optically pure pseudohexopyranoses and a pseudopentofuranose, carbocyclic analogs of hexopyranoses and pentofuranose. Synthesis of derivatives of (1S,2S,3R,4S,5S)-, (1S,2S,3R,4R,5S)-, (1R,2R,3R,4R,5S)-, (1S,2S,3R,4S,5R)-2,3,4,5-tetrahydroxy-1-(hydroxymethyl)cyclohexanes and (1S,2S,3S,4S)-2,3,4-trihydroxy-1(hydroxymethyl)cyclopentane J. Org. Chem. 1987, 52, 1946– 1956 DOI: 10.1021/jo00386a011
        [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      81. 81
        McMurry, J. E.; Dushin, R. G. Total synthesis of (±)-crassin by titanium-induced pinacol coupling J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1989, 111, 8928– 8929 DOI: 10.1021/ja00206a031
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        81
        Total synthesis of (±)-crassin by titanium-induced pinacol coupling
        McMurry, John E.; Dushin, R. G.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1989), 111 (24), 8928-9CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        Key steps in the synthesis of the antitumor cembrane lactone crassin (I) are the Ti-induced pinacol coupling of lactone keto aldehyde II to yield dihydroxy lactone III (R = α-OH) and the double stereochem. inversion of III (R = α-OH) to yield III (R = β-OH). Translactonization and methylenation then complete the synthesis. The synthesis demonstrates a potentially important extension of the Ti-induced carbonyl coupling reaction by showing that complex, polyoxygenated macrocycles can be produced.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXmtlehtbs%253D&md5=6f587095979fbb7ced23782d57282de6
      82. 82
        Kikuchi, H.; Okazaki, K.; Sekiya, M.; Uryu, Y.; Ueda, K.; Katou, Y.; Kurata, S.; Oshima, Y. Synthesis and innate immunosuppressive effect of 1,2-cyclopentanediol derivatives Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2011, 46, 1263– 1273 DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2011.01.049
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
